misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to read coordinates of two points and compute the Euclidean distance between them, instead of reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100 and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade: A for 90–100, B for 80–89, C for 70–79, D for 60–69, and F for below 60.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1 and y1, x2 and y2 instead of a single grade value.
Program computes a square root of squared coordinate differences instead of using if/else logic to classify a grade.
There are no conditional statements mapping numeric ranges to letter grades.
The output message reports a distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this task with a different assignment (distance between two points) and not translating the given grading specification into code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and identify the required inputs (one numeric grade), the processing (checking which range the grade falls into using if/else), and the correct outputs (letter grade A–F). Then redesign the program around this specification, removing the distance-formula code.
related_concepts: Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
Mapping numeric input to categorical output
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All inputs, computations, and outputs in the submission correspond to a distance-between-points problem and none to a grade calculator; there is no trace of grade-related logic.

evidence.note: All variables, prompts, and computations relate to coordinates and distance, with no numeric-grade input or letter-grade classification as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program (Distance Calculator) that is entirely unrelated to the required task (Grade Calculator). The code reads four coordinate values and calculates the distance, failing to address any of the requirements related to reading a grade or applying conditional logic for letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment required me to calculate the distance between two coordinates.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment (Q3) requires reading one numerical grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Input prompts ask for four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2)
The main calculation uses the distance formula `Math.sqrt(...)`
The output reports a distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about which programming problem to submit/solve for Q3, resulting in submission of code for a completely different typical programming exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the Q3 prompt carefully and rewrite the entire program to focus solely on reading a single grade and applying the grading scale using `if`/`else if` statements to output the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is a verbatim solution to the Euclidean Distance problem, which has zero overlap with the Grade Calculator problem requirements.

evidence.note: The variable names and input prompts indicate the program is asking for coordinates for a distance calculation, not a single grade input (0-100).

evidence.snippet:
d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The core logic calculates the distance formula, confirming the submission addresses a problem other than the Grade Calculator.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misunderstanding - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution to a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem between two points in 2D space, not a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the provided scale.
symptoms: Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of performing grade range checking
Output displays distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have copied or submitted code from a different assignment (likely a previous distance calculation problem) without reading or understanding the Q3 requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. Q3 asks for a grade calculator. You need to: (1) Read one numeric grade as input, (2) Use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: With 99% confidence - the submission is objectively solving a different problem entirely. The code implements distance calculation, not grade classification. This is not ambiguous or partial understanding; it's the wrong problem entirely.

evidence.note: The entire program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates and calculates Euclidean distance. This is not a grade calculator at all.

evidence.snippet:
System.out.print("Enter x1 and y1: ");
System.out.print("Enter x2 and y2: ");
evidence.note: Program prompts for coordinates instead of prompting for a numeric grade as specified in Q3 requirements and sample run.

misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong problem (distance calculation instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter-grade calculator. The program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2), computes a distance with the distance formula, and prints that distance, instead of reading a single numeric grade (0–100), using conditional ranges to determine A/B/C/D/F, and printing the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), compute the distance between them using the distance formula, and print that distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, determine which letter grade range it falls into using conditionals (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60), and then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
No conditionals or range checks for grade intervals (90–100, 80–89, etc.)
Output describes distance between two points instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements: the student wrote a solution for a distance-formula problem rather than the specified grade-calculator problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required input (a single numeric grade) and output (a letter grade). Then redesign the program: read one grade value, use if/else-if statements to check which numeric range it falls into, and print only the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping problem description to input and output
Designing conditionals based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure (variables x1, y1, x2, y2, use of distance formula, and printed message) matches a distance-between-points problem and contains no elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinates, computes a Euclidean distance, and prints it, with no handling of a single numeric grade or letter-grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).

Code prompts for four points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade input
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific requirements for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and replace the distance calculation logic with the required input reading and conditional structure (if-else if-else) for grading.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code calculates Euclidean distance, which is factually unrelated to the specified grade calculation task (Q3).

evidence.note: The code calculates the distance between two points, completely ignoring the grade calculation requirement.

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: The student has solved an entirely different problem (distance calculator for two points) instead of the grade calculator specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving a distance formula problem using coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) and the Euclidean distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting a letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified grading scale.

Uses distance formula instead of conditional logic for grades
No conditional branches to check grade ranges
No letter grade output - outputs the calculated distance instead
This solution would fail all test cases for the grade calculator
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either submitted code from a different assignment, completely misread the problem statement, or copied incorrect code without understanding the requir ements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. The program should: (1) prompt for and read a single numeric grade, (2) use if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into, (3) output the corresponding letter grade.
